docs.lead_paragraph: The HBO documentary “Paycheck to Paycheck” follows the ordinary but grindingly difficult life of one single mother over the course of a year.

headline.seo: HBO’s ‘Paycheck to Paycheck’: A Single Mother’s Struggle
headline.main: Barely Treading Water at $9.49 an Hour
headline.print_headline: Barely Treading Water at $9.49 an Hour

docs.abstract: Neil Genzlinger reviews HBO television documentary Paycheck to Paycheck: The Life and Times of Katrina Gilbert.
docs.snippet: The HBO documentary “Paycheck to Paycheck” follows the ordinary but grindingly difficult life of one single mother over the course of a year.

headline.main: Shouldn't the Breast Pump Be as Elegant as an iPhone and as Quiet as a Prius by Now?

docs.abstract: That noise? It’s the motor, not the suction, and a half-ton hybrid vehicle is quieter. And what product designer actually thought women wanted to see their nipples getting sucked into small tubes over and over again?
docs.snippet: That noise? It’s the motor, not the suction, and a half-ton hybrid vehicle is quieter. And what product designer actually thought women wanted to see their nipples getting sucked into small tubes over and over again?

byline.original: By COURTNEY E. MARTIN and JOHN CARY

docs.lead_paragraph: Two counties, separated by fortune and 350 miles, demonstrate the widening divide in life expectancy between affluent and struggling areas of the United States.

headline.main: Income Gap, Meet the Longevity Gap
headline.print_headline: Income Gap, Meet the Longevity Gap

docs.abstract: Wealthy Fairfax County, Va, and blue-collar McDowell County, W Va, illustrate the growing divide in life expectancy between affluent and struggling areas of the United States; gap has widened over past decade, with men living an average of 82 years in Fairfax and only 64 years in McDowell.
docs.snippet: Two counties, separated by fortune and 350 miles, demonstrate the widening divide in life expectancy between affluent and struggling areas of the United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: As government financing of basic research has fallen off precipitously, philanthropists have stepped in, setting priorities and drawing both gratitude and trepidation from scientists.

headline.main: Billionaires With Big Ideas Are Privatizing American Science
headline.print_headline: Billionaires With Big Ideas Are Privatizing American Science

docs.abstract: So-called Brain initiative announced by Pres Obama underscores how American science, long a source of national power and pride, is increasingly becoming a private enterprise; as government financing of basic research has fallen off precipitously, many of America's richest philanthropists have stepped in, setting priorities and drawing both gratitude and trepidation from scientists.
docs.snippet: As government financing of basic research has fallen off precipitously, philanthropists have stepped in, setting priorities and drawing both gratitude and trepidation from scientists.

docs.lead_paragraph: The president’s sinking ratings, a loss in a House election in Florida and millions of dollars spent by Republican-aligned groups attacking the new health law are complicating matters.

headline.main: Obama Factor Adds to Fears of Democrats
headline.print_headline: Obama Factor Adds to Fears of Democrats

docs.abstract: Democrats are becoming increasingly alarmed about their midterm election fortunes amid Pres Obama's sinking approval ratings; adding to their alarm is the loss of a special House election in Florida and millions of dollars spent by Republican-aligned groups attacking the new health law; interviews with Democrats reveal a new urgency over addressing the party's prospects.
docs.snippet: The president’s sinking ratings, a loss in a House election in Florida and millions of dollars spent by Republican-aligned groups attacking the new health law are complicating matters.

docs.lead_paragraph: 1) Raise the rent often. 2) No coin laundry. 3) Don’t be a slumlord.

headline.main: The Cold, Hard Lessons of Mobile Home U.
headline.print_headline: The Cold, Hard Lessons of Mobile Home U.

docs.abstract: Gary Rivlin article profiles Rank Rolfe, who teaches a three-day course in the art of buying and operating mobile-home parks; says what is striking about Rolfe's business is how happy the tenants who live in the parks are, and how people involved in the enterprise may represent the best thing going in affordable housing at a time when the need has never been greater.
docs.snippet: 1) Raise the rent often. 2) No coin laundry. 3) Don’t be a slumlord.

docs.lead_paragraph: In his first months on the job, Virginia Gov. Terry McAullife is trying to capitalize on Democrats' takeover of top state offices and the state Senate by pushing a key element of President Barack Obama's health care law through a Republican-dominated House of Delegates.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration was trying to address consumers’ concerns that costs were too high and that the choice of doctors, hospitals and prescription drugs was too limited.

headline.main: White House Tightens Health Plan’s Standards After Consumers Complain
headline.print_headline: White House Tightens Health Plan’s Standards After Consumers Complain

docs.abstract: Obama administration issues stringent new standards for health insurance to address complaints from consumers who say costs are too high and choice of doctors, hospitals and prescription drugs is too limited in many health plans offered under the Affordable Care Act; officials say they will scrutinize plans more closely for 2015.
docs.snippet: The Obama administration was trying to address consumers’ concerns that costs were too high and that the choice of doctors, hospitals and prescription drugs was too limited.

docs.lead_paragraph: The de Blasio administration is seeking a deal with the union that would let New York City stretch out potentially huge retroactive pay raises.

headline.main: De Blasio Pushes a 9-Year Contract for Teachers
headline.print_headline: De Blasio Pushes a 9-Year Contract for Teachers

docs.abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio is pushing for a record nine-year contract with the teacher's union that would allow city to stretch out potentially huge retroactive pay increases; administration has said city cannot afford to immediately pay $3.4 billion that union has demanded; contract is likely to set pattern for city's other municipal unions, which are also demanding billions in retroactive raises, making negotiations all the more tricky.
docs.snippet: The de Blasio administration is seeking a deal with the union that would let New York City stretch out potentially huge retroactive pay raises.
